Second Republic | term_start2 = 1 October 1969 | term_end2 = 12 January 1972 | predecessor2 = [[Kofi Asante Ofori-Atta]]
(First Republic) | successor2 = [[Jacob Hackenburg Griffiths-Randolph]]
Third Republic | constituency2 = | majority2 = | order3 = [[Judge|Justice]] of the [[Supreme Court of Ghana]] | term_start3 = | term_end3 = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1906|5|21|df=y|}} | birth_place = [[Accra]], [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]][https://books.google.com/books?id=cgkzAQAAIAAJ&q=Nii+Amaa+Ollennu+1906&dq=Nii+Amaa+Ollennu+1906&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xo4LT4y-C5SOigLZ4_mKBA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ ''Review of Ghana Law'', Volume 12] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170914134351/https://books.google.com/books?id=cgkzAQAAIAAJ&q=Nii+Amaa+Ollennu+1906&dq=Nii+Amaa+Ollennu+1906&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xo4LT4y-C5SOigLZ4_mKBA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ |date=2017-09-14 }}, General Legal Council, 1980. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1986|12|22|1906|5|21|df=y}} | death_place = | nationality = {{flagicon|GHA}} Ghanaian | constituency = | party = | spouse = Nana Afua Frema
(Queen-mother of Wenchi) | relations ={{unbulleted list|[[Kofi Abrefa Busia]] (brother-in-law)|[[Gottlieb Ababio Adom]] (cousin)|[[Nathan Quao]] (cousin)|[[Amon Nikoi]] (nephew)|[[Nicholas T. Clerk]] (nephew)|[[George C. Clerk]] (nephew)|[[Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu]] (grandnephew)}} | profession = {{hlist|[[Lawyer]]|[[Judge]]}} | education = {{unbulleted list|[[Presbyterian College of Education, Akropong|Presbyterian Training College, Akropong]]|[[Middle Temple]]}} | religion = | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Raphael Nii Amaa Ollennu''' (21 May 1906 – 22 December 1986){{cite web|url=http://rulers.org/rulg1.html#ghana |title=Rulers - Ghana |accessdate=2007-03-24 |work=List of heads of state and heads of Government |publisher=Rulers.org |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403074857/http://www.rulers.org/rulg1.html |archivedate=2007-04-03 |df= }} was a [[jurist]] and [[judge]] who became a Justice of the [[Supreme Court of Ghana]], the acting [[President of Ghana]] during the [[Busia government|Second Republic]] from 7 August 1970 to 31 August 1970 and the [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] of the [[Parliament of Ghana]] from 1969 to 1972. ==Early life and education== Ollennu was born in [[Labadi Beach|Labadi]], Accra in 1906 and belonged to the [[Ga-Adangbe people|Ga people]].{{cite book |last=Lentz |first=Harris M. |date=4 February 2014 |title=Heads of States and Governments Since 1945 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D6HKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA317&dq=Edward+Akufo-Addo+born&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false |location= |publisher=Routledge |page=317 |isbn=978-1-134-26490-2 |author-link= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170914134351/https://books.google.com/books?id=D6HKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA317&dq=Edward+Akufo-Addo+born&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false |archivedate=14 September 2017 |df= }} His parents were Wilfred Kuma Ollennu and Salomey Anerkai Mandin Abbey.{{Cite web|url=https://www.myheritage.com/names/nii_ollennu|title=Nii Ollennu - Historical records and family trees - MyHeritage|website=www.myheritage.com|access-date=2018-02-04|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180205001046/https://www.myheritage.com/names/nii_ollennu|archivedate=2018-02-05|df=}} Ollennu attended the middle boarding school, the [[Salem School, Osu|Salem School]] at [[Osu, Accra|Osu]] .{{Cite web|url=http://osusalem.org/pages/aboutus.php?parentpage=aboutus&page=history|title=Osu Salem|website=osusalem.org|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329141604/http://osusalem.org/pages/aboutus.php?parentpage=aboutus&page=history|archivedate=2017-03-29|deadurl=yes|access-date=2017-06-24|df=}} Part of his earlier education was at the [[Presbyterian College of Education, Akropong|Presbyterian Training College]] at [[Akropong]] in the [[Eastern Region, Ghana|Eastern Region]] of Ghana, where he studied [[pedagogy]] and [[theology]].{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/GhanaHome/NewsArchive/news_details.asp?id=VFZSQmVVNVVTWGs9&menu_id=4&sub_menu_id=386&menu_id2=0&gender=Feature_Article|title=When Dancers play Historians and Thinkers - Part 10|author=Dr. Kwame Okoampa-Ahoofe, Jr|date=31 August 2006|work=Feature Article|publisher=Modern Ghana Homepage|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190846/http://www.warc.ch/where/ugc/02.html|archivedate=27 September 2007|deadurl=no|accessdate=2007-03-25|df=}} He went to [[England]] to study [[jurisprudence]] at the [[Middle Temple]], and was called to the Bar in a record 18 months, earning recognition from the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Queen's Council]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.uidaho.edu/law/news/features/2015/nii-amaa-ollennu|title=Destined to be a Lawyer - College of Law - University of Idaho|website=www.uidaho.edu|language=en|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629073009/http://www.uidaho.edu/law/news/features/2015/nii-amaa-ollennu|archivedate=2017-06-29|deadurl=no|access-date=2017-09-14|df=}} == Legal career == The first person in his family to qualify as a [[lawyer]], he was registered as Raphael Nii Amaa Ollennu in the [[Gold Coast (British Colony)|Gold Coast]] (now Ghana) register in 1940.{{cite web|url=http://www.judicial.gov.gh/history/list_lawyers/home.htm|title=Lawyers Enrolled in the Roll Books (1876 - 1997)|work=Official Website|publisher=Judicial Service of Ghana|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050414064831/http://www.judicial.gov.gh/history/list_lawyers/home.htm|archivedate=2005-04-14|accessdate=2007-03-24|quote=}} He later became a [[judge]] and a Justice of the [[Supreme Court of Ghana]].{{Cite web|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C10136878|title=The Discovery Service|last=Archives|first=The National|website=discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-09-09}} He also published books on various legal topics and was an authority on traditional African land-tenure system. He was also actively involved with the General Council of the [[World Alliance of Reformed Churches]].{{cite web|url=http://www.warc.ch/where/ugc/02.html|title=Proceedings|work=The official record of the 20th general council of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches and the 11th assembly of the International Congregational Council held in Nairobi, Kenya, during the period 20–30 August 1970|publisher=The World Alliance of Reformed Churches|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190846/http://www.warc.ch/where/ugc/02.html|archivedate=2007-09-27|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2007-03-25|quote=Dr Pradervand announced that greetings had been received, through the high commissioner of Ghana, from the Hon Justice Nii Amaa Ollennu, who was unable to attend the council because of his responsibilities in the Ghanaian government.|df=}} ==Politics == Nii Amaa Ollennu was one of the Accra representatives in the Gold Coast [[Legislative Assembly]] during the early 1950s. He once led the [[Ghana Congress Party]], which along with the [[United Gold Coast Convention]] and the National Democratic Party, was a party of the [[J.B. Danquah|Danquah]]-[[Kofi Abrefa Busia|Busia]] tradition. Ollennu was thus in opposition alongside Busia and Danquah to Nkrumah's [[Convention People's Party]]. ==Interim President of Ghana== During the second republic, Ollennu was the [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] of the [[Parliament of Ghana]] from October 1969 to January 1972. He also became the acting [[president of Ghana]] on 7 August 1970. He was officially the chairman of the Presidential Commission. He took over from the previous military leader, [[Akwasi Afrifa|Lt. Gen. Afrifa]] and handed over on 31 August 1970 to [[Edward Akufo-Addo]] who was elected on 31 August 1970 by an electoral college. He polled 123 votes to 35 by Edward Asafu Adjaye. This was a [[ceremonial presidency]] as executive power was held by the prime minister, [[Kofi Abrefa Busia]]. During the Second Republic of Ghana, Ollennu served as [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] of the [[Parliament of Ghana]]. == Personal life and family == Nii Amaa Ollennu was married to a sister of Prime Minister [[Kofi Abrefa Busia|Busia]], Nana Afua Frema, the [[Queen mothers (Africa)|Queenmother]] of [[Wenchi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hawafoundation.org/personality%20talk.htm|title=Personality Talk|work=Official Website|publisher=The Hawa Foundation and Organization|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070502190250/http://www.hawafoundation.org/personality%20talk.htm|archivedate=2007-05-02|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2007-03-25|quote=Mrs. Amerley Awua Asamoa"...."My father was the late Justice Nii Amaa Ollennu (a renowned Jurist and Speaker of Parliament, 2nd Republic of Ghana). My mother is Nana Afua Frema, former Queen-mother of Wenchi and direct sister of the late Dr. Kofi Abrefa Busia (Prime Minister of the 2nd Republic).|df=}} Nii Amaa Ollennu was the cousin of [[Gottlieb Ababio Adom]] (1904 –1979), an [[Education|educator]], [[Editor-in-chief|editor]], [[journalist]] and [[Presbyterian polity|Presbyterian minister]] who served as the [[Editor-in-chief|Editor]] of the [[Christian Messenger (Ghana)|Christian Messenger]], the official newspaper of the [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana]] from 1966 to 1970.{{Cite book|title=Obituary: The Reverend Gottlieb Ababio Adom,|last=|first=|date=29 June 1979|publisher=Presbyterian Church of Ghana, Funeral Bulletin|isbn=|location=Accra|pages=}} Another cousin was [[Nathan Quao]] (1915 – 2005), a [[diplomat]], [[Education|educationist]] and [[Civil service|public servant]] who became a [[presidential advisor]] to many [[List of heads of state of Ghana|Heads of State of Ghana]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/74014/nathan-quao-to-be-given-state-burial-on-april-8.html|title=Nathan Quao to be given state burial on April 8|work=ModernGhana.com|access-date=2017-06-11|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.myheritage.com/names/carl_clerk|title=Carl Clerk - Historical records and family trees - MyHeritage|website=www.myheritage.com|access-date=2018-11-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170406111341/https://www.myheritage.com/names/carl_clerk#|archive-date=2017-04-06|dead-url=no|df=}} Ollennu was the cousin of the Quao siblings whose progeny included [[Amon Nikoi]] (1930 – 2002), an [[economist]] and [[diplomat]], the [[Governor]] of the [[Bank of Ghana]] from 1973 to 1977 and [[Finance minister]] from 1979 to 1981 in addition to the brothers, [[Nicholas T. Clerk]] (1930 – 2012), a former [[Rector (academia)|Rector]] of the [[Ghana Institute of Management and Public Administration|GIMPA]] and [[George C. Clerk]] (born 1931), the [[botanist]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Former-Bank-of-Ghana-Governor-buried-at-La-28089|title=Former Bank of Ghana Governor buried at La|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170421092109/http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Former-Bank-of-Ghana-Governor-buried-at-La-28089|archivedate=21 April 2017|deadurl=no|access-date=2017-04-22|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/people/person.php?ID=171|title=Dr Amon Nikoi, Former Governor of the Bank of Ghana|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027192942/http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/people/person.php?ID=171|archivedate=27 October 2016|deadurl=no|access-date=2017-04-22|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ug.edu.gh/botany/visitors/contact_us|title=Contact Us {{!}} Department of Botany|website=webcache.googleusercontent.com|access-date=2017-04-05|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329232450/http://www.ug.edu.gh/botany/visitors/contact_us|archivedate=29 March 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://gaas-gh.org/fellowship/membership/|title=Membership|website=gaas-gh.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-05|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329143021/http://gaas-gh.org/fellowship/membership/|archivedate=29 March 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://gaas-gh.org/fellowship/|title=Fellowship|website=gaas-gh.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-05|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330011437/http://gaas-gh.org/fellowship/|archivedate=30 March 2017|df=}}{{Cite book|title=Obituary: The Rev. Dr. Nicholas Timothy Clerk|last=|first=|date=27 October 2012|publisher=Christian Messenger - Presbyterian Church of Ghana, Funeral Bulletin|year=|isbn=|location=Accra|pages=}} [[Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu]], a [[NASA]] robotics engineer, is Ollennu's grandnephew.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180808121953/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/technology-40306617/five-robots-that-are-changing-everything#|title=Five robots that are changing everything - BBC News|date=2018-08-08|access-date=2018-11-21}} ==Death== Nii Amaa Ollennu died in December 1986. ==Bibliography== *{{cite book |last='''Ollennu''' |first='''Nii Amaa''' |authorlink=Nii Amaa Ollennu |title=Principles of Customary Land Law in Ghana |edition= |series=Law in Africa Volume 2 |year=1962 |publisher= Sweet and Maxwell |location=London |isbn= |oclc=877770 |doi= |id= }} *{{cite book |last=Humphrey |first=J. |authorlink= |author2=Fiseer, N. A. |author3='''Ollennu, Nii Amaa''' |title=The Law of Testate and Intestate Succession in Ghana |series=Law in Africa Volume 16 |year=1966 |publisher= Sweet and Maxwell |location=London |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id=B0000CN89R }} *{{cite book |last='''Ollennu''' |first='''Nii Amaa''' |authorlink=Nii Amaa Ollennu |author2=Gordon R. Woodman |editor= |others= |title=Ollennu's Principles of Customary Land Law in Ghana |edition=2nd |year=1985 |publisher=CAL Press |location=Birmingham |isbn=978-0-9510530-0-3}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Kofi Asante Ofori-Atta]]
(1965 – 66)}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] of the [[Parliament of Ghana]]
Second Republic |years=1969 – 711}} {{s-aft|after=[[Jacob Hackenburg Griffiths-Randolph]]
(1979 – 81)}} {{s-bef|before=[[Akwasi Afrifa]]
Military Head of state}} {{s-ttl|title=[[President of Ghana]]
(Chair of Presidential Commission) |years=1970}} {{s-aft|after=[[Edward Akufo-Addo]]}} {{s-ref|1=*[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927045829/http://www.parliament.gh/leadershipdetails.php?id=0003 Source from Ghana Government]}} {{SpeakerGhanaParliament}} {{Heads of State of Ghana}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ollennu, Nii Amaa}} [[Category:Acting Presidents of Ghana]] [[Category:Speakers of the Parliament of Ghana]] [[Category:Justices of the Supreme Court of Ghana]] [[Category:Ghanaian judges]] [[Category:Ghanaian lawyers]] [[Category:1906 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:Place of death missing]] [[Category:Ga-Adangbe people]] [[Category:Ghana Congress Party politicians]] [[Category:Ghanaian Presbyterians]] [[Category:Ghanaian Protestants]] [[Category:Gold Coast (British colony) judges]] [[Category:Members of the Middle Temple]] [[Category:People from Accra]]

{{Infobox artist | name = Nuha al-Radi | image = Photo of Nuha al-Radi.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1941|1|27|mf=y}} | birth_place = Baghdad, Iraq | death_date = {{death date and age|2004|8|30|1941|1|27|mf=y}} | death_place = Beirut, Lebanon | nationality = Iraqi | education = Byam Shaw School of Art, the American University in Beirut | field = Painting, Ceramics, Sculpture, Writing | training = | movement = | works = ''Baghdad Diaries'' | patrons = | awards = | spouse = }}
'''Nuha al-Radi''' (January 27, 1941, [[Baghdad]] – August 30, 2004, [[Beirut]]) was an [[Iraq]]i [[diarist]], [[ceramist|ceramicist]] and [[Painting|painter]] and noted author of the ''Baghdad Diaries'' which vividly recounts the horror of living through the first Gulf War.
==Life and career==
She was born into a distinguished Iraqi family which included [[Mahmoud Shawkat]], the last Prime Minister of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1919, her father [[Mohammed Selim al-Radi]] was one of the first Iraqis to be educated in the United States when he studied agriculture in [[Texas]]. He married [[Suad Abbas]], became an Iraqi [[diplomat]] and was appointed ambassador to [[Iran]] in 1947 and then to India from 1949 to 1958, where Nuha al-Radi grew up. She was educated at private [[English language|English-speaking]] schools in [[Delhi]] and [[Shimla|Simla]], except for a brief spell in 1956 when she attended a boarding school in [[Alexandria]] to improve her [[Arabic language|Arabic]], but this was interrupted by the [[Suez Crisis]].<ref>al-Radi, N., ''Baghdad Diaries: A Woman's Chronicles of War and Peace,'' Vintage Books, 2003, p. 7; "Nuha al-Radi," [Obituary], ''The Guardian, 7 September, 2007 [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/sep/07/guardianobituaries.iraq Online:]</ref>
After the [[14 July Revolution|Iraqi Revolution]] broke out in 1958 and the monarchy was overthrown, Nuha al-Radi became a ceramist, having joined the [[Byam Shaw School of Art]] in [[London]] and later worked with [[Chelsea Pottery]]. She returned to Baghdad and exhibited in Iraq, Britain and Europe. In 1969, her family moved to Beirut and where she graduated in liberal arts from the [[American University]] in [[Beirut]] She also taught there and continued to work and exhibit as a ceramist, but the outbreak of the [[Lebanese civil war]] forced her to return to Baghdad.<ref>"Nuha al-Radi," [Obituary], ''The Guardian, 7 September, 2007 [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/sep/07/guardianobituaries.iraq Online:]</ref>
In 1991, after the first three days of bombing in [[Gulf War|Operation Desert Storm]], she began writing a diary in English. This was first published as "''Baghdad Diary''” and then translated into [[Dutch language|Dutch]]. She continued updating it until 1996. In 1998 her eyewitness account of the [[Gulf War]] and its aftermath was published as "''Baghdad Diaries''" and translated into several languages. The 2003 edition of the book includes a postscript with remarks on the American invasion of Iraq.<ref>{{cite book|last=al-Radi|first=Nura|title=Baghdad Diaries: A Woman's Chronicle of War and Exile|year=2003|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|isbn=1-4000-7525-4|pages=213–217}}</ref>
She died in 2004 from [[leukemia]].<ref>"Nuha al-Radi," [Obituary], ''The Guardian, 7 September, 2007 [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/sep/07/guardianobituaries.iraq Online:]; "''Baghdad Diaries'' author Nuha Al Radi dies in Beirut," ''Gulf News,'' 8 September, 2004, [https://gulfnews.com/news/mena/iraq/baghdad-diaries-author-nuha-al-radi-dies-in-beirut-1.331968 Online:]</ref> She and her family believed that the leukemia may have been caused by the depleted uranium allies had fired at the tanks during the Gulf war. <ref>"Memory of late Nuha al-Radi lives on through her art," ''Daily Star,'' (Lebanon), 8 September, 2004 [http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Culture/Art/2004/Sep-08/93263-memory-of-late-nuha-al-radi-lives-on-through-her-art.ashx Online:]</ref>
==Work== Her works have been exhibited throughout the Arab world.<ref>"Nuha al-Radi," [Obituary], ''The Guardian, 7 September, 2007 [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/sep/07/guardianobituaries.iraq Online:]</ref> Her ceramic works are often inspired by Iraqi folklore.<ref>Hann, G., Dabrowska, K. and Greaves, T.Y., ''Iraq: The Ancient Sites and Iraqi Kurdistan,'' Bradt Travel Guides, 2015, p. 109</ref>
She has been praised for offering a uniquely female perspective on the male-centred business of war, occupation and economic sanctions in both her writing and her artwork. <ref>Mehta, B., "Dissidence, Creativity, and Embargo Art in Nuha Al-Radi's ''Baghdad Diaries,''" ''Meridians: Feminism, Race and Transnationalism,'' Vol. 6, No. 2, 2006, pp. 220-235</ref>
===Publications=== Her book, ''Baghdad Diaries'' recounts the horrific experiences of living through the first Gulf war. <ref>Gomaa, F.M.A. "Re-membering Iraqis in Nuha al-Radi’s Baghdad Diaries: A Woman’s Chronicle of War and Exile," ''Feminist Formations,'' Vol 29, No. 1, 2017, pp. 53-70 {{doi|10.1353/ff.2017.0003}}</ref>
'''Select list of publications''' * ''Baghdad Diaries: A Woman's Chronicles of War and Peace,'' Vintage Books, (1998) 2003
==See also== * [[Iraqi art]] * [[Islamic art]] * [[List of Iraqi artists]] * [[List of Iraqi women artists]]
== References == {{Reflist}} * Muneeza Shamsie, Independent scholar. "Nuha al-Radi." The Literary Encyclopedia. 10 Feb. 2003. The Literary Dictionary Company. 17 December 2006. <http://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec=true&UID=5215>
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Phra Bisal Sukhumvit Seripharb Magazine.jpg|thumb|Phra Bisal Sukhumvit]] '''Phra Bisal Sukhumvit''' ([[Thai language|Thai]]: พระพิศาลสุขุมวิท), born ''Prasob Sukhum'' (ประสพ สุขุม) was the fifth chief of the [[Ministry of Transport (Thailand)|Department of Highways]] in [[Thailand]]. [[Sukhumvit Road]], one of Thailand's major highways, is named after him.
== Education == He was the son of Chao Phraya Yommaraj (Pun Sukhum), regent to [[King Rama VIII]] and Minister of the Interior from 1922 - 1926.
Prasop studied in the United States at [[Phillips Exeter Academy]] (class of 1919)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.exeterthailand.org/history/founders|title=Founders & First Thai Students - Exeter Association of Thailand|website=www.exeterthailand.org|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref> and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] (class of 1923), graduating from Course I <ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://thaiembdc.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Part3Elephant.pdf|title=The Eagle and the Elephant - Thai-American Relations Since 1833|last=|first=|publisher=Royal Thai Embassy, Washington, D.C.|year=2009|isbn=978-0-9764391-2-7|edition=5th|location=|pages=145|orig-year=1982}}</ref> with his dissertation titled "A study of traffic at Governor Square, Boston, with suggestions for its regulation".<ref>{{Cite thesis|last=Sukhum|first=Prasob|title=A study of traffic at Governor Square, Boston, with suggestions for its regulation|date=1923-01-01|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/study-of-traffic-at-governor-square-boston-with-suggestions-for-its-regulation/oclc/37423693|language=English}}</ref> He was the first Thai person to graduate from MIT. While in college, he formed a musical duo with Phisit Arthacinta called the 'Siamese Twins', which according to a review in ''Brooklyn Life'' consisted of "some of the more famous Siamese songs, together with interpretations of American ragtime".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/83157333/|title=Brooklyn Life from Brooklyn, New York on December 11, 1920 · Page 11|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}}</ref> He was a founder of the American University Alumni Association and was later the chairman of the organization for 39 years.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:Sukhumvit Phillips Exeter Academy Yearbook 1919.png|thumb|Prasop Sukhum's yearbook entry at Phillips Exeter Academy]]
== Career == Returning to Thailand he became an assistant engineer at the Department of Sanitation and as his career progressed, he was responsible for a rapid increase in Thailand's road infrastructure during the 1930s and 1940s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=|title=Stuck in Traffic: the History of Transportation in Bangkok|url=https://www.amchamthailand.com/asp/view_doc.asp?DocCID=1979|journal=Thai-American Business|volume=3/2008}}</ref>
He was the Director General of the Royal Irrigation Department in 1942–3.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://oknation.nationtv.tv/blog/political79-2/2015/01/21/entry-2|script-title=กำเนิดกรมชลประทาน(กรมคลอง) ด้วยพระบารมี ร.5|trans-title=The founding of the Department of Irrigation (Department of Canals) through the ''barami'' of Rama V|language=th|website=oknation.nationtv.tv|access-date=2017-04-11}}</ref>
He was part of the [[Free Thai Movement]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sukhumvit-road.com/history.html|title=History of the Sukhumvit Road|website=www.sukhumvit-road.com|access-date=2017-04-11}}</ref> and was part of a delegation sent to the United States by [[Pridi Banomyong]] at the end of World War II. This delegation aimed to positively influence the United States in assisting Thailand with post-war reconstruction despite [[Japan–Thailand relations#World War II: occupation and alliance|Thailand's support for Japan during the war]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=F8puAAAAMAAJ|title=The Eagle and the elephant: Thai-American relations since 1833|last=Phongphiphat|first=Wimon|last2=Phongphiphat|first2=Naphā|date=1987-01-01|publisher=United Production}}</ref> He addressed the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs]] and sought assistance from [[Abbot Low Moffat]] who headed the South East Asian Affairs Division of the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] which helped improve [[Thailand–United States relations]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://thaiembdc.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Part1EagleElephant-1.pdf|title=The Eagle and the Elephant - Thai-American Relations Since 1833|last=|first=|publisher=Royal Thai Embassy, Washington, D.C.|year=2009|isbn=978-0-9764391-2-7|edition=5th|location=|pages=75–76|orig-year=1982}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bisal Sukhumvit, Phra}} [[Category:Urban planners]] [[Category:Thai people]]

revision.text:
'''Ronny Fredrik Ansnes''' (28 June 1989 – c.15 July 2018) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[cross-country skier]].
He made his [[FIS Cross-Country World Cup|World Cup]] debut in February 2011 in [[Drammen]], also breaking the top 15-barrier with a 13th place in the 15 kilometre race. He also finished second in a relay race in November 2011 in [[Sjusjøen]]. Ansnes also contested the [[Holmenkollen ski festival|Holmenkollen 50 kilometre race]] in 2012 and 2013 and a World Cup race in [[La Clusaz]] in January 2013 before retiring in 2014.<ref name=bio>{{FIS|S=CC|ID=129334}}</ref> He also won an individual silver medal at the Norwegian Championships, the 15 kilometre race in 2012, as well as a relay bronze medal in 2010.<ref name=death/>
He hailed from [[Klæbu]]<ref name=death>{{cite news|url=https://www.vg.no/sport/langrenn/i/WLA4oj/den-tidligere-langrennsloeperen-ronny-fredrik-ansnes-er-doed|title=Den tidligere langrennsløperen Ronny Fredrik Ansnes er død|last=Haram|first=Ola|date=18 July 2018|work=VG|language=Norwegian|accessdate=18 July 2018}}</ref> and represented the sports club [[Byåsen IL]].<ref name=bio/>
Ansnes drowned in July of 2018 in the Resa river in Resdalen, [[Meldal]]. He was found on 16 July, probably having drowned on the previous day.<ref name=death/> He was 29.
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = | name = Said al-Muragha | honorific_suffix = | native_name = سعيد مُراغة | native_name_lang = Ar | image = Fatah-al-intifada-abu-musa.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1927 | death_date = 29 January 2013 | birth_place = [[Silwan]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] | death_place = [[Damascus]], [[Syria]] | placeofburial = Damascus, Syria | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = Abu Musa | birth_name = | allegiance = [[Jordan]] (1948-1970)
[[PLO]] (1970-1983)
[[Fatah al-Intifada]] (1983-2013) | branch = [[Jordanian Army]] | serviceyears = | rank = [[Colonel]] | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = | battles = [[Lebanon Civil War]] *[[1982 Lebanon War]] **[[Siege of Beirut]] *[[War of the Camps]] | battles_label = | awards = | memorials = | spouse = | relations = | laterwork = Secretary-General of [[Fatah al-Intifada]] | signature = | website = | module = }} [[Col.]] '''Sa'eed Musa al-Muragha''' ({{lang-ar|سعيد مُراغة or سعيد موسى}}) (born 1927 in [[Silwan]]{{cite news | title = Musa Muragha, Saeid (Abu Musa) | publisher = Dictionary of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict | date = 2005-01-01 | accessdate = 2010-07-31 | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3434400751.html}} – 29 January 2013)[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Jan-29/204211-pro-syria-palestinian-commander-dies.ashx#axzz2JPOG3D00 Pro-Syria Palestinian commander dies] was a [[Palestinian militant]] better known as '''Abu Musa'''. ==Early years== A [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]], Abu Musa joined the [[Jordanian Army]] in 1948 and rose to become commander of an [[artillery]] battalion in 1969. During this period he was sent to receive a military education at the prestigious [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Sandhurst Military Academy]].{{cite book |title= Revolution until victory?: the politics and history of the PLO |last= Rubin |first= Barry M. |year= 1994 |publisher= Harvard University Press |isbn= 0-674-76803-5 |page= 62 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=zbQKILIgAwQC&dq=}} In October 1970, after the [[Black September in Jordan|Black September fighting]], Musa left the Jordanian army to join the [[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO]] and relocated with most of the Palestinian Resistance to [[Lebanon]]. Here Musa rose to command an alliance between the PLO and Lebanese militias, which fought the [[Syria]]ns when Syria intervened in the [[Lebanese Civil War]] in 1976.{{cite news | title = Abu Musa | publisher = Encyclopedia of World Biography | date = 2004-01-01 | accessdate = 2010-07-31 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3404700038.html}} In 1978 the Syrian government unsuccessfully attempted to assassinate him. ==Split with Arafat== Musa became deputy chief of operations for the PLO and [[Siege of Beirut|led the PLO's defense of Beirut]] in 1982 from the [[Israel]]is. However Musa fell out with [[Yassir Arafat]], head of Fatah and PLO, in May 1983. Musa publicly complained over corrupt practices within the PLO, especially the promotion of political appointees loyal to Arafat to important military posts. He was also known for hardline views on [[Israel]], and outspoken in his opposition to what he saw as Arafat's attempt to reach a negotiated solution to the conflict (see [[Rejectionist Front]]). In November 1983 Musa was expelled from the PLO's military and he formed [[Fatah Uprising]] (or [[Fatah al-Intifada]] in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]) in opposition to Arafat. With the backing of Syria, who opposed any negotiations with Israel, Musa led his followers to drive Arafat's PLO from northern Lebanon. In 1984 Musa led Fatah Uprising to join the [[Palestinian National Alliance]] in [[Damascus]] in opposition to the PLO but failed to get a majority of Palestinian support. He would join the [[Palestinian National Salvation Front]] in 1985 and oppose the [[Oslo Accords]] in 1993. Abu Musa retreated from his leadership role in the 1990s and would no longer be active from then on. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Muragha, Said}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Palestinian militants]] [[Category:Rebels]]

{{more footnotes|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox military person |name= Samuel Thompson Busey |birth_date= {{birth date|1835|11|16}} |death_date= {{death date and age|1909|8|12|1835|11|16}} |birth_place= [[Greencastle, Indiana|Greencastle]], [[Indiana]] |death_place= [[Mantrap Township, Hubbard County, Minnesota|Mantrap Township]], [[Minnesota]] |placeofburial= Woodlawn Cemetery
[[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]], [[Illinois]] |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |image= Samuel Thompson Busey.jpg |caption= Samuel Thompson Busey |allegiance= [[United States of America]]
[[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] |branch= [[United States Army]]
[[Union Army]] |serviceyears= 1861-1865 |rank= [[File:Union Army colonel rank insignia.png|35px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]]
[[File:Union Army brigadier general rank insignia.svg|35px]] [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] |commands= [[76th Illinois Volunteer Infantry Regiment]] |unit= |battles= [[American Civil War]] |awards= |laterwork= }} '''Samuel Thompson Busey''' (November 16, 1835 – August 12, 1909) was a [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] from [[Illinois]]. ==Biography== Samuel Busey was born in [[Greencastle, Indiana]] but moved with his parents to [[Urbana, Illinois]]. He attended the public schools and went on to study law where he attended commercial college and law lectures in 1859 and 1860. During the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] he served as [[first sergeant]] and then [[first lieutenant]] of the [[Urbana Zouaves]] in 1861 and 1862. He was appointed Town collector in 1862 and became a [[second lieutenant]] in the recruiting service in June 1862 and helped to organize the [[76th Illinois Volunteer Infantry Regiment|Seventy-sixth Regiment, Illinois Volunteer Infantry]] where he served as [[Captain (OF-2)|captain]] of Company B of that regiment June 22, 1862. He later served as a [[lieutenant colonel]] August 22, 1862 and was promoted to [[colonel]] January 7, 1863. On July 20, 1866, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Andrew Johnson]] nominated Busey for appointment to the grade of [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] of volunteers, to rank from April 9, 1865, and the [[United States Senate]] confirmed the appointment on July 26, 1866.Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-3641-1}}. p. 741. He mustered out of the service July 22, 1865, in [[Chicago, Illinois]] and engaged in banking from 1867 to 1888. He later served as mayor of Urbana 1880-1889. Busey was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[52nd United States Congress|Fifty-second]] Congress (March 4, 1891 – March 3, 1893) defeating [[Joseph Gurney Cannon]]. He was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1892 to the [[53rd United States Congress|Fifty-third]] Congress, losing to Cannon (who regained his seat). This pattern would be repeated 22 years later by fellow Democrat banker [[Frank T. O'Hair]]. After, his failed reelection he returned to banking. He died in a boating accident in [[Mantrap Township, Hubbard County, Minnesota]] August 12, 1909 while on a family vacation. His niece, Annie McClain, was killed in the same accident.Champaign Daily Gazette, August 13, 1909, p. 1. He was interred in Woodlawn Cemetery, [[Urbana, Illinois]]. ==See also== {{Portal|United States Army|American Civil War}} *[[List of American Civil War brevet generals (Union)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{CongBio|B001164}} Retrieved on 2008-10-19 {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Illinois | district=15 | before=[[Joseph Gurney Cannon]] | after=[[Joseph Gurney Cannon]] | years=March 4, 1891 – March 3, 1893}} {{s-end}} {{Bioguide}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Busey, Samuel Thompson}} [[Category:1835 births]] [[Category:1909 deaths]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Illinois]] [[Category:Union Army colonels]] [[Category:Illinois Democrats]] [[Category:Democratic Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Minnesota]] [[Category:People from Greencastle, Indiana]] [[Category:People from Urbana, Illinois]] [[Category:Boating accident deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]]

{{other uses}} {{in popular culture|date=August 2018}}
[[File:Nekyia Staatliche Antikensammlungen 1494 n2.jpg|thumb|alt=Sisyphus depicted on a black-figure amphora vase |[[Persephone]] supervising Sisyphus in the [[Greek underworld|Underworld]], [[Attica]] black-figure [[amphora]] (vase), {{circa|530}} BC, [[Staatliche Antikensammlungen]]<ref>museum {{abbr|inv.|inventory number}} 1494</ref>]]
In [[Greek mythology]] '''Sisyphus''' or '''Sisyphos''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|ɪ|s|ɪ|f|ə|s}}; {{lang-grc-gre|Σίσυφος}}, ''{{transl|grc|Sísuphos}}'') was the king of [[Cichyrus|Ephyra]] (now known as [[Corinth]]). He was punished for his self-aggrandizing craftiness and deceitfulness by being forced to roll an immense boulder up a hill only for it to roll down when it nears the top, repeating this action for eternity. Through the [[classicism|classical influence]] on modern culture, tasks that are both [[wikt:laborious#Adjective|laborious]] and [[wikt:futile#Adjective|futile]] are therefore described as '''Sisyphean''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|s|ɪ|s|ɪ|ˈ|f|iː|ən}}).<ref>{{OED|sisyphean}}</ref>
== Etymology == Linguistics Professor [[Robert S. P. Beekes|R. S. P. Beekes]] has suggested a [[pre-Greek]] origin and a connection with the root of the word ''{{transl|grc|sophos}}'' (σοφός, "wise").<ref>[[Robert S. P. Beekes|R. S. P. Beekes]], ''Etymological Dictionary of Greek'', Brill, 2009, p. xxxiii.</ref> German [[mythographer]] [[Otto Gruppe]] thought that the name derived from ''{{transl|grc|sisys}}'' (σίσυς, "a goat's skin"), in reference to a rain-charm in which goats' skins were used.<ref>Gruppe, O. ''Griechische Mythologie'' (1906), ii., p. 1021</ref>
== Family == Sisyphus was the son of King [[Aeolus (son of Hellen)|Aeolus]] [[Thessaly|of Thessaly]] and [[Enarete]].<ref>[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Pseudo-Apollodorus]]. ''[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+1.7.3&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022:book=1:chapter=7&highlight=Sisyphus Bibliotheca, 1.7.3]''</ref> He was the father of [[Glaucus (son of Sisyphus)|Glaucus]], [[Ornytion]], [[Almus (son of Sisyphus)|Almus]], and [[Thersander]] by the nymph [[Merope (Pleiades)|Merope]], the brother of [[Salmoneus]], and the grandfather of [[Bellerophon]] through Glaucus.<ref name=":0">Pseudo-Apollodorus. ''Bibliotheca, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Apollod.+1.9.3&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022:book=1:chapter=9&highlight=Sisyphus 1.9.3]''</ref><ref name="Homer Iliad VI 152ff">[[Homer]], ''[[Iliad]]'' VI 152ff</ref>
== Mythology == {{Greek myth (Hades)}}
=== Reign === Sisyphus was the founder and first king of Ephyra (supposedly the original name of [[Ancient Corinth|Corinth]]).<ref name=":0" /> King Sisyphus promoted navigation and commerce but was avaricious and deceitful. He also killed travellers and guests, a violation of ''[[Xenia (Greek)|xenia]]'', which fell under [[Zeus]]'s domain. He took pleasure in these killings because they allowed him to maintain his iron-fisted rule.
=== Conflict with Salmoneus === Sisyphus and his brother Salmoneus were known to hate each other, and Sisyphus consulted with the [[Oracle]] of [[Delphi]] on just how to kill Salmoneus without incurring any severe consequences for himself. From [[Homer]] onward, Sisyphus was famed as the craftiest of men. He seduced Salmoneus's daughter [[Tyro]] in one of his plots to kill Salmoneus, only for Tyro to slay the children she bore him when she discovered that Sisyphus was planning on using them eventually to dethrone her father.
=== Cheating death === King Sisyphus also betrayed one of Zeus's secrets by revealing the whereabouts of [[Aegina (mythology)|Aegina]], (an [[Asopides|Asopid]] who was taken away by Zeus) to her father (the river god [[Asopus]]) in return for causing a spring to flow on the Corinthian [[acropolis]].<ref name=":0" />
Zeus then ordered [[Thanatos]], Death, to chain King Sisyphus down below in [[Tartarus]]. Sisyphus was curious as to why [[Hermes]], whose job it was to guide souls to the Underworld, had not appeared on this occasion. King Sisyphus slyly asked Thanatos to demonstrate how the chains worked. As Thanatos was granting him his wish, Sisyphus seized the opportunity and trapped Thanatos in the chains instead. Once Thanatos was bound by the strong chains, no one died on earth. This caused an uproar especially for [[Ares]] (who was annoyed that his battles had lost their fun because his opponents would not die), and so he intervened. The exasperated Ares freed Thanatos and turned King Sisyphus over to Thanatos.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oup.com/us/companion.websites/0195153448/studentresources/chapters/ch25/?view=usa |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629173245/http://www.oup.com/us/companion.websites/0195153448/studentresources/chapters/ch25/?view=usa |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In another version, [[Hades]] was sent to chain Sisyphus and was chained himself. As long as Hades was tied up, nobody could die. Because of this, sacrifices could not be made to the gods, and those that were old and sick were suffering. The gods finally threatened to make life so miserable for Sisyphus that he would wish he were dead. He then had no choice but to release Hades.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mlahanas.de/Greeks/Death.htm |title=Ancient Greeks: Is death necessary and can death actually harm us? |publisher=Mlahanas.de |date= |accessdate=2014-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702053105/http://mlahanas.de/Greeks/Death.htm |archivedate=2 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Before King Sisyphus died, he had told his wife to throw his naked body into the middle of the public square (purportedly as a test of his wife's love for him). This caused King Sisyphus to end up on the shores of the river [[Styx]]. Then, complaining to [[Persephone]], goddess of the Underworld, that this was a sign of his wife's disrespect for him, King Sisyphus persuaded her to allow him to return to the upper world. Once back in Ephyra, the spirit of King Sisyphus scolded his wife for not burying his body and giving it a proper funeral (as a loving wife should). When King Sisyphus refused to return to the Underworld, he was forcibly dragged back there by Hermes.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}}<!-- (This version is alluded to by [[Albert Camus|Camus]] without citation and also appears in [[Roberto Bolaño]]'s novel ''2666'', in a context that indicates it may have been made up rather than traditional.) --> In another version of the myth, Persephone was tricked by Sisyphus that he had been conducted to [[Tartarus]] by mistake, and so she ordered that he be released.<ref>Bernard Evslin's ''gods, Demigods & Demons'', 209–210</ref>
In ''[[Philoctetes]]'' by [[Sophocles]], there is a reference to the father of [[Odysseus]] (rumoured to have been Sisyphus, and not [[Laërtes]], whom we know as the father in the ''[[Odyssey]]'') upon having returned from the dead.
=== Punishment in the Underworld === As a punishment for his trickery, King Sisyphus was made to endlessly roll a huge boulder up a steep hill.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-eng2:11.13-11.13 |title=Homeros, Odyssey, 11.13 |publisher=Perseus Digital Library |date= |accessdate=2014-10-09}}</ref><ref name="Odyssey, xi. 593">''[[Odyssey]]'', xi. 593</ref> The maddening nature of the punishment was reserved for King Sisyphus due to his [[hubris]]tic belief that his cleverness surpassed that of Zeus himself. Zeus accordingly displayed his own cleverness by enchanting the boulder into rolling away from King Sisyphus before he reached the top, which ended up consigning Sisyphus to an eternity of useless efforts and unending frustration. Thus it came to pass that pointless or interminable activities are sometimes described as ''Sisyphean''. King Sisyphus was a common subject for ancient writers and was depicted by the painter [[Polygnotus]] on the walls of the [[Lesche]] at [[Delphi]].<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] x. 31</ref>
==Interpretations== [[File:Johann-Vogel-Meditationes-emblematicae-de-restaurata-pace-Germaniae MGG 1020.tif|thumb|alt=Black and white etching of Sisyphus by Johann Vogel |Sisyphus as a symbol for continuing a senseless war. Johann Vogel: ''Meditationes emblematicae de restaurata pace Germaniae'', 1649]] According to the [[solar theory]], King Sisyphus is the disk of the sun that rises every day in the east and then sinks into the west.<ref name="eb1911">{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Sisyphus |volume=25 |page=161}}</ref> Other scholars regard him as a personification of waves rising and falling, or of the treacherous sea.<ref name="eb1911"/> The 1st-century BC [[Epicureanism|Epicurean]] philosopher [[Lucretius]] interprets the myth of Sisyphus as personifying politicians aspiring for political office who are constantly defeated, with the quest for power, in itself an "empty thing", being likened to rolling the boulder up the hill.<ref>''[[De Rerum Natura]]'' III</ref> [[Friedrich Welcker]] suggested that he symbolises the vain struggle of man in the pursuit of knowledge, and [[Salomon Reinach]]<ref>''Revue archéologique'', 1904</ref> that his punishment is based on a picture in which Sisyphus was represented rolling a huge stone [[Acrocorinthus]], symbolic of the labour and skill involved in the building of the Sisypheum. [[Albert Camus]], in his 1942 essay ''[[The Myth of Sisyphus]]'', saw Sisyphus as personifying the absurdity of human life, but Camus concludes "one must imagine Sisyphus happy" as "The struggle itself towards the heights is enough to fill a man's heart." More recently, [[J. Nigro Sansonese]],<ref>[[J. Nigro Sansonese|Sansonese, J. Nigro]]. ''The Body of Myth.'' Rochester, 1994, pp. 45–52. {{ISBN|0-89281-409-8}}</ref> building on the work of [[Georges Dumézil]], speculates that the origin of the name "Sisyphos" is onomatopoetic of the continual back-and-forth, susurrant sound ("siss phuss") made by the breath in the nasal passages, situating the mythology of Sisyphus in a far larger context of archaic (see [[Proto-Indo-European religion]]) trance-inducing techniques related to breath control. The repetitive inhalation–exhalation cycle is described esoterically in the myth as an up–down motion of Sisyphus and his boulder on a hill.
In experiments that test how workers respond when the meaning of their task is diminished, the test condition is referred to as the Sisyphusian condition. The two main conclusions of the experiment are that people work harder when their work seems more meaningful, and that people underestimate the relationship between meaning and motivation.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ariely|first=Dan|title=The Upside of Irrationality|year=2010|isbn=0-06-199503-7}}</ref>
In his book ''The Philosophy of Recursive Thinking''<ref>Manfred Kopfer (2018); The Philosophy of Recursive Thinking, The recursive solution for Sisyphos problem. {{ISBN|978-3-7438-7149-6}}</ref> German author Manfred Kopfer suggested a viable solution for Sisyphus punishment. Every time Sisyphus reaches the top of the mountain, he breaks off a stone from the mountain and carries it down to the lowest point. This way, the mountain will eventually be levelled and the stone cannot roll down anymore. In Kopfers interpretation, the solution turns the punishment by the gods into a test for Sisyphus to prove his worthiness for godlike deeds. If Sisyphus is able "to move a mountain", he shall be allowed to do what otherwise only gods are entitled to do.
===Literary interpretations=== [[File:Punishment sisyph.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Painting of Sisyphys by Titian |''Sisyphys'' (1548–49) by [[Titian]], [[Prado Museum]], [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]]] [[File:Syzyfki (Sisyphers) Wroclaw dwarf 01.JPG|''Syzyfki''|thumb|alt=Sisypher dwarves sculpture by Tomasz Moczek. Two small bronze figures stand either side of a stone sphere. |''Sisypher'' dwarves by {{Interlanguage link multi|Tomasz Moczek|pl}} in [[Wrocław]]]] [[Homer]] describes Sisyphus in both Book VI of the ''[[Iliad]]'' and Book XI of the ''[[Odyssey]]''.<ref name="Homer Iliad VI 152ff"/><ref name="Odyssey, xi. 593"/>
[[Ovid]], the Roman poet, makes reference to Sisyphus in the story of [[Orpheus]] and [[Eurydice]]. When Orpheus descends and confronts Hades and Persephone, he sings a song so that they will grant his wish to bring Eurydice back from the dead. After this song is sung, Ovid shows how moving it was by noting that Sisyphus, emotionally affected, for just a moment, stops his eternal task and sits on his rock, the Latin wording being ''inque tuo sedisti, Sisyphe, saxo'' ("and you sat, Sisyphus, on your rock").<ref>Ovid. ''Metamorphoses'', 10.44.</ref>
In [[Plato]]'s ''[[Apology (Plato)|Apology]]'', Socrates looks forward to the after-life where he can meet figures such as Sisyphus, who think themselves wise, so that he can question them and find who is wise and who "thinks he is when he is not"<ref>Apology, 41a</ref>
[[Albert Camus]], the [[French Algeria|French]] [[absurdism|absurdist]], wrote an essay entitled ''[[The Myth of Sisyphus]]'', in which he elevates Sisyphus to the status of absurd hero. [[Franz Kafka]] repeatedly referred to Sisyphus as a bachelor; [[Kafkaesque]] for him were those qualities that brought out the Sisyphus-like qualities in himself. According to Frederick Karl: "The man who struggled to reach the heights only to be thrown down to the depths embodied all of Kafka's aspirations; and he remained himself, alone, solitary."<ref>[[Frederick Karl|Karl, Frederick]]. ''Franz Kafka: Representative Man.'' New York: International Publishing Corporation, 1991. p. 2</ref> The philosopher [[Richard Taylor (philosopher)|Richard Taylor]] uses the myth of Sisyphus as a representation of a life made meaningless because it consists of bare repetition.<ref>Taylor, Richard. "Time and Life's Meaning." ''Review of Metaphysics'' 40 (June 1987): 675–686.</ref>
[[Wolfgang Mieder]] has collected cartoons that build on the image of Sisyphus, many of them [[editorial cartoons]].<ref>Wolfgang Mieder. 2013. Neues von Sisyphus: Sprichtwortliche Mythen der Antike in moderner Literatur, Medien und Karikaturen. Vienna: Praesens.</ref>
==In popular culture== ===Games=== *Sisyphus is the main character in the video game ''[[Rock of Ages (video game)|Rock of Ages]]'' (2011), in which he travels through several time periods with a giant boulder defeating his enemies, including the Greek titan [[Cronus]], who serves as the main villain of the story. Sisyphus' appearance is based on the black figure Amphora.
===Literature=== *King Sisyphus is featured in ''[[Percy Jackson & the Olympians]]'', in ''[[The Demigod Files]]'' story titled "The Sword of Hades", in which Percy Jackson, Thalia Grace, and Nico di Angelo follow the trail of the person that stole the Sword of Hades to Sisyphus' area in the Fields of Punishment. Percy and Nico ask him for advice while Thalia pushes the boulder up the hill. As they leave, Sisyphus begs them to set him free. * ''[[The Myth of Sisyphus]]'', a 1942 philosophical essay by [[Albert Camus]]
===Television=== *[[List of Hercules: The Legendary Journeys and Xena: Warrior Princess characters#Main characters|King Sisyphus]] was featured in the ''[[Hercules: The Legendary Journeys]]'' and ''[[Xena: Warrior Princess]]'' TV series, voiced by Ray Henwood in "Death in Chains" and "Highway to Hades", and by [[Charles Siebert]] in "Ten Little Warlords". *A version of King Sisyphus appeared in the animated series ''[[Ulysses 31]]'', in the episode "The Eternal Punishment": Zeus offers Sisyphus a way out of his punishment if he manages to replace in the pit the traveler Ulysses, who is journeying throughout unknown space to find a way home. *Referenced in The Deuce S1E5
===Music===
*Sisyphus is referenced in the song "[[Clutch (Clutch album)|Rock & Roll Outlaw]]", released in 1995 on the self titled album "[[Clutch discography|Clutch]]" by [[Clutch (band)|Clutch]]. The referencing lyric is "[[Clutch (Clutch album)|You can rock it like Sir Sisyphus]]". *Sisyphus is referenced in the song "[[Over and Over and Over]]", released in 2018 on the album [[Boarding House Reach]] by [[Jack White]]. The reference reoccurs throughout the song in the line, "[https://genius.com/Jack-white-over-and-over-and-over-lyrics The Sisyphean dreamer...]<ref>{{Citation|last=JackWhiteVEVO|title=Jack White - Over and Over and Over|date=2018-03-23|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ShCRN3tFy80|access-date=2018-10-30}}</ref>" *Sisyphus is referenced in the song "Only Skin," released in 2006 on the album "[[Ys (Joanna Newsom album)|Ys]]" by [[Joanna Newsom]].
==See also== * [[Sisyphus cooling]], a cooling technique named after the Sisyphus myth * ''[[Syzyfowe prace]]'', a novel by Stefan Żeromski * [[The Hill (film)|''The Hill'' (film)]] * ''[[Triangle (2009 British film)|''Triangle'' (2009 British film)]] *Comparable characters: ** [[Naranath Bhranthan]], a willing boulder pusher in Indian folklore ** [[Tantalus]] – tormented also in the Underworld ** [[Wu Gang]] – also tasked with the impossible: to fell a self-regenerating tree

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Skinny Dennis | image = Heartworn Highways Screenshot Skinny Dennis Sanchez.png | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Dennis Sanchez | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1946|09|03|mf=y}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1975|03|20|1946|09|03}} |death_place =[[Sunset Beach, California|Sunset Beach]], [[California]], [[United States]] | origin = | instrument = [[Double bass]] | genre = [[Country music|Country]]
[[Folk music|Folk]] | occupation = | years_active = 1970–1975 | label = | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Skinny Dennis Sanchez''' (September 3, 1946 – March 20, 1975) was a country musician in the Los Angeles area.Interview with James Szalapski done by Thomas W. Campell, 1996. He played the upright bass, most famously accompanying Nashville musician [[Guy Clark]] during Clark's stay in Los Angeles.Michael K Harris: Booklet Heartworn Highway DVD. His nickname is in reference to his having [[Marfan syndrome]];{{citation|last=Saviano|first=Tamara|title=Without Getting Killed or Caught: The Life and Music of Guy Clark|publisher=[[Texas A&M University Press]]|page=126|ISBN=978-1623494544}} Sanchez stood at 6'11", and weighed 135 lbs.Graham Lees: ''[http://www.noshow.freewire.co.uk/dvdheartwornhighways.htm Review of DVD Heartworn Highways] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630135941/http://www.noshow.freewire.co.uk/dvdheartwornhighways.htm |date=2007-06-30 }}''. He is most famously mentioned in the Guy Clark song "L.A. Freeway" (recorded by Guy Clark on his debut album, [[Old No. 1]] in 1975 and first recorded by [[Jerry Jeff Walker]] in 1972). Clark's lyrics went as follows: "Here's to you ol' Skinny Dennis
The only one I think I will miss
I can hear your ol' bass singin'
Sweet and low like a gift you're bringin'" Sanchez was also friends with many in Clark's circle, including [[Townes Van Zandt]], [[Rodney Crowell]], [[Steve Earle]], [[Richard Dobson]] and others. A documentary featuring the aforementioned songwriters, "Heartworn Highways," is dedicated to Sanchez. Richard Dobson recorded Sanchez' song "Bus Stop Coffee" for his albums ''In Texas Last December'' and ''One Bar Town''. Sanchez died at age 28 of heart failure on stage, playing the bass at Captain Jack's in Sunset Beach with John Penn. The Skinny Dennis Brooklyn bar in New York City is named after Sanchez.http://www.skinnydennisbar.com/about/ (accessed March 24, 2018) == References == {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dennis, Skinny}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]] [[Category:Musicians who died on stage]] [[Category:American double-bassists]] [[Category:20th-century American musicians]] [[Category:American country bass guitarists]] [[Category:Male bass guitarists]] [[Category:People with Marfan syndrome]] [[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]

{{Infobox scientist | name = Sunil K. Ahuja | image = SunilAhujaMD.jpg | birth_date = 13 March 1961 | fields = [[Genetics]], [[immunology]], [[molecular biology]] | workplaces = {{Plainlist| * Center for Personalized Medicine (director, 2009-present) * [[University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio]] (professor, 2002-present) * VA Center for HIV and AIDS Infection ([[San Antonio]]) (2001-present) * [[Audie L. Murphy Memorial VA Hospital]] (1996-present) }} | education = {{Plainlist| * [[University of Alberta]] (M.S., 1986) * [[Armed Forces Medical College (India)]] (M.D., 1983) * [[SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn]] (residency) }} }}
'''Sunil Kumar Ahuja, M.D.''' (born March 13, 1961)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mdjunction.com/doctor/sunil-kumar-ahuja/20623 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-05-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120905233700/http://www.mdjunction.com/doctor/sunil-kumar-ahuja/20623 |archivedate=2012-09-05 |df= }}</ref> is a professor of Medicine, Microbiology, Immunology & Biochemistry at the [[University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio]] and an expert on the role of immunogenetics on [[HIV]] pathogenesis. Dr. Ahuja is also the Director of the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Veterans Administration]] Research Center for AIDS and HIV-1 Infection. His most recent work, first published in the 2005 issue of [[Science (journal)|Science]], involves the ethnic group-specific role of [[CCR5]] haplotype and [[CCL3L1]] gene copy number on the progression of HIV to AIDS.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2005/01/06/science.1101160|title=The Influence of CCL3L1 Gene-Containing Segmental Duplications on HIV-1/AIDS Susceptibility|first1=Enrique|last1=Gonzalez|first2=Hemant|last2=Kulkarni|first3=Hector|last3=Bolivar|first4=Andrea|last4=Mangano|first5=Racquel|last5=Sanchez|first6=Gabriel|last6=Catano|first7=Robert J.|last7=Nibbs|first8=Barry I.|last8=Freedman|first9=Marlon P.|last9=Quinones|first10=Michael J.|last10=Bamshad|first11=Krishna K.|last11=Murthy|first12=Brad H.|last12=Rovin|first13=William|last13=Bradley|first14=Robert A.|last14=Clark|first15=Stephanie A.|last15=Anderson|first16=Robert J.|last16=O'Connell|first17=Brian K.|last17=Agan|first18=Seema S.|last18=Ahuja|first19=Rosa|last19=Bologna|first20=Luisa|last20=Sen|first21=Matthew J.|last21=Dolan|first22=Sunil K.|last22=Ahuja|date=6 January 2005|publisher=|journal=Science|accessdate=12 August 2017|via=www.sciencemag.org|doi=10.1126/science.1101160|pmid=15637236}}</ref>
==Education== Sunil Ahuja received his medical degree from the Armed Forces Medical College India in 1983.<ref name="texasmonthly.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/2008-02-01/feature9.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704205650/http://www.texasmonthly.com/2008-02-01/feature9.php |archivedate=2008-07-04 |df= }}</ref> Following work towards a [[M.Sc.]] degree from the [[University of Alberta]] in Canada, Dr. Ahuja had his internship and residency at the [[SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn]].
==Publications== Sunil Ahuja's research has been published in many high-profile [[peer-review]]ed journals, including Science, [[Nature Medicine]], [[Nature Immunology]] and [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]].
==Honors== Sunil Ahuja has been the recipient of many honors and awards, including being named in 2001 the [[Elizabeth Glaser]] Scientist and the Burroughs Wellcome Clinical Scientist in Translational Research.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uthscsa.edu/opa/issues/new34-2/ahuja.html|title=Awards|website=www.uthscsa.edu|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="uthscsa.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.uthscsa.edu/hscnews/singleformat.asp?newID=1776|title=News - UT Health Science Center San Antonio - UT Health Science Center News|website=UT Health Science Center News|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref> In 2005 he also was the recipient of the MERIT award from the [[National Institutes of Health]]. Less than 5% of NIH-funded researchers receive this award.<ref name="uthscsa.edu"/>
In February 2008 Dr. Ahuja was listed as one of 35 people that will shape our future by [[Texas Monthly]] magazine.<ref name="texasmonthly.com"/>
==Scientific disagreements==
Some of Sunil Ahuja's work has been questioned by the scientific community. In July 2008 Sunil Ahuja's group reported that Duffy antigen receptor for chemokines ([[DARC (gene)]]) influenced HIV/AIDS susceptibility.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines Mediates trans-Infection of HIV-1 from Red Blood Cells to Target Cells and Affects HIV-AIDS Susceptibility|vauthors=He W, Neil S, Kulkarni H, Wright E, Agan BK, Marconi VC, Dolan MJ, Weiss RA, Ahuja SK |journal=Cell Host Microbe |year=2008 |volume=4|pages=52–62 |pmid=18621010 |doi=10.1016/j.chom.2008.06.002|issue=1|pmc=2562426}}</ref> This finding was then questioned by four groups of scientists, reporting the failure to replicate.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines Null Promoter Variant Does Not Influence HIV-1 Acquisition Or Disease Progression |vauthors=Walley NM, Julg B, Dickson SP, etal |journal=Cell Host Microbe |year=2009 |volume=5|pages=408–410 |pmid=19454339 |doi=10.1016/j.chom.2009.04.011|issue=5|pmc=2720554}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Expression of Duffy antigen receptor for chemokines (DARC) has no effect on HIV-1 acquisition or progression to AIDS in African Americans|vauthors=Winkler CA, An P, Johnson R, Nelson GW, Kirk G |journal=Cell Host Microbe |year=2009 |volume=5|pages=411–413 |pmid=19454340 |doi=10.1016/j.chom.2009.04.010|issue=5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Lack of Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines: No Influence on HIV Disease Progression in an African Treatment Naïve Population |vauthors=Julg B, Reddy S, van der Stok M, etal |journal=Cell Host Microbe |year=2009 |volume=5|pages=413–415 |pmid=19454341 |doi=10.1016/j.chom.2009.04.009|issue=5|pmc=2749504}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Duffy antigen polymorphisms do not alter progression of HIV in African Americans in the MACS cohort |vauthors=Horne KC, Li X, Jacobson LP, etal |journal=Cell Host Microbe |year=2009 |volume=5|pages=415–417 |pmid=19454342 |doi=10.1016/j.chom.2009.04.013|issue=5}}</ref> Sunil Ahuja replied to the questioning in the same issue of ''[[Cell Host & Microbe]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Author reply|journal=Cell Host Microbe |year=2009 |volume=5|pages=418–419 |doi=10.1016/j.chom.2009.05.007}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Tach Sharakat | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Bumburet]], [[Kalasha Desh]], [[Pakistan]] | birthname = Taj Khan Kalash | othername = | occupation = | spouse = |alma_mater = [[Edwardes College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[Aristotle University of Thessaloniki]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[Central European University]] ([[Master of Arts|M.A.]]) | website = [http://www.kalashapeople.org/ www.KalashaPeople.org] }} '''Tach Sharakat Kalash''' (born '''Taj Kalas''') belongs to an endangered [[Indigenous culture]] and language community [[Kalash people|Kalasha]] (an [[Indigenous peoples|Indigenous people]] group) living in the wilderness of [[Hindu Kush]] Mountains in the Chitral district of [[Pakistan]]. Kalasha are the last remaining [[Paganism|pagan]] tribe numbering 4000 people{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} speaking the ancient Indo-Aryan language [[Kalasha-mun|Kalasha-mondr]]. They practice a [[Polytheism|polytheistic]] ancestral belief system and Pre-Islamic culture dating back to 3000 B.C.Jarde, A. (2013). The Formation of the Greek People (History of the Early Civilization) . Routledge. ISBN B00GO057H6. Tach is one of the first literates among Kalasha People to have received BA in Political science & Law at [[Edwardes College]] Peshawar Pakistan, a 2nd BA in English Literature & Linguistics at [[Aristotle University of Thessaloniki]] and MA Human Rights from [[Central European University]] Budapest, Hungary. Tach has made first Kalasha indigenous documentary film Kalasha{{cite web |url= http://www.filmfestival.gr/docfestival/2003/uk/process_en.php?movieid=579&eventid=103|title=Kalasha |date=March 3, 2003 |publisher=5th [[Thessaloniki Documentary Festival]]|accessdate=2009-07-08}} about his people as part of anthropological documentation and advocacy for Kalasha people's linguistic rights in education and cultural autonomy. He is also writer of first hand report on "Kalasha Mythology, herbs & Shamanic practices". Tach has been a spokesman for Kalasha with his exceptional linguistic skills speaking four Asiatic and three European languages besides his mother tongue. Working in close collaboration with various international researchers and linguists Taj organized first Kalasha Orthography Conference 2000{{cite web | url=http://kalasha.org/pages/the-kalasha-alphabet-book/orthography.php | title=Orthography Conference | publisher=Kalasha | accessdate=10 August 2014}} in Islamabad, Pakistan. In 2004 he was able to raise funds to publish first alphabet book of Kalasha language based on Roman script designed by an Australian linguist Gregory R. Cooper. Tach's struggles for survival & development of Kalasha language are featured in a recent documentary film called The Alphabet Bookhttp://www.patternfilms.com/alphabet/home produced by [http://www.patternfilms.com Pattern films]. He is currently working on developing Kalasha Literacy Project that involves documentation of [[Kalasha-mun|Kalash language]] and Oral historical data by compilation of textbooks and literacy materials in Kalasha language. ==See also== * [[Kalash people|Kalasha People]] * [[Kalasha-mun|Kalash language]] * [[Bumburet]] * [[Kafiristan]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * http://www.athensnews.gr/old_issue/13006/9564 * http://sprogmuseet.dk/enkeltsprog/kalasha-i-danmark/ {{authority control}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kalash people]] [[Category:Linguists from Pakistan]] [[Category:Pakistani human rights activists]] [[Category:People from Chitral District]] [[Category:Edwardes College alumni]] [[Category:Aristotle University of Thessaloniki alumni]] [[Category:Central European University alumni]] {{Pakistan-activist-stub}} {{pakistan-linguist-stub}}

'''Takahashi Seisakusho''' is a Japanese manufacturer of telescopes and related equipment, such as eyepieces and mounts.
Often known simply as 'Tak', the brand is especially noted amongst amateur astronomers for its range of [[apochromatic]] [[refractor]]s, but also produces various types of [[Reflecting telescope|reflectors]], and instruments featuring compound optics.
Takahashi pioneered the use of [[fluorite]] crystal in place of one of the glass elements in the objective lens of an astronomical telescope, although this material had previously been used in other optical devices.<ref>Lizaso, Iñaki. "[http://www.astrosurf.com/ilizaso/Takahashi%20FCT-100/FCT.htm Fluorite Refracting Telescopes]".</ref> The company's name would become synonymous with the use of this type of crystal.
In recent years however, Takahashi has produced some telescopes using [[Low dispersion glass|extra-low dispersion ("ED")]] FPL-53 glass<ref>FPL-53 is a type of glass manufactured by Ohara GmbH. "[http://www.ohara-gmbh.com/e/produkte/astro.html Optical Glass for Astronomical Applications]".</ref> in place of fluorite in the [[objective lens]].
High-performance glass that contains fluorine should not be confused with fluorite crystal, which is not glass.
Some other telescope manufacturers use Takahashi refractors as collimating instruments for larger telescopes.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.takahashijapan.com/index.html Takahashi Seisakusho website. (Japanese language only.)] * [http://takahashiamerica.com Takahashi America] * [http://www.takahashi-europe.com/en/index.php Takahashi Europe. (English and French language.)]
[[Category:Telescope manufacturers]] [[Category:Japanese brands]]
{{japan-company-stub}}

{{for|the Grimsby Town football player|Tom Paul (footballer)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Tom Paul | honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=NZL|CBE}} | image = File:Tom Paul 1919.jpg | alt = | caption = | office = | primeminister = | deputy = | term_start = | term_end = | predecessor = | successor = | office1 = Member of the [[New Zealand Legislative Council]] | term_start1 = 22 January 1907 | term_end1 = 25 November 1919 | primeminister1 = [[Joseph Ward]]
[[Thomas Mackenzie]]
[[William Massey]] | term_start2 = 9 September 1946 | term_end2 = 31 December 1950 | primeminister2 = [[Peter Fraser]]
[[Sidney Holland]] | office3 = 3rd President of the [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] | term_start3 = 1918 | term_end3 = 1920 | leader3 = [[Alfred Hindmarsh]]†
[[Harry Holland]] | vicepresident3 = [[Michael Joseph Savage]]
[[Peter Fraser]] | predecessor3 = [[Andrew Walker (politician)|Andrew Walker]] | successor3 = [[Peter Fraser]] | birth_date = 16 August 1874 | birth_place = [[Boort, Victoria]], [[Australia]] | death_date = 25 July 1964 | death_place = [[Raumati]], [[Kapiti Coast]], [[New Zealand]] | citizenship = | nationality = New Zealand | party = [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]]
[[United Labour Party (New Zealand)|United Labour Party]]
[[Independent Political Labour League|IPLL]] | otherparty = | spouse = | partner = | relations = | children = | parents = | residence = | education = | occupation = | profession = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''John Thomas "Tom" Paul''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|CBE|size=85%}} (16 August 1874 – 25 July 1964) was a New Zealand compositor, trade unionist, politician, editor, journalist and censor. ==Biography== Paul was born in [[Boort, Victoria]], Australia in 1874.{{DNZB|title=John Thomas Paul|first= Erik|last= Olssen|id=3p16|accessdate=23 April 2017}} He came to New Zealand in 1899.{{sfn|Gustafson|1980|p=164}} Paul was a journalist and printer and became President of the [[Otago]] Typographical Workers Union in 1902. He was appointed to the [[New Zealand Legislative Council]] on 22 January 1907. At the expiry of his term, he was reappointed on 22 January 1914, but resigned on 25 November 1919 to stand for Labour in the general election after the popular [[Thomas Sidey]] had announced that he would retire from the [[Dunedin South]] electorate.{{sfn|Gustafson|1980|p=155}} He was appointed again on 9 September 1946 and served until the abolition of the Legislative Council on 31 December 1950; thus serving for sixteen years in total.{{sfn|Wilson|1985|p=161}} He was deeply involved with the early development of the Labour Party, from establishing the [[Independent Political Labour League]] via the [[New Zealand Labour Party (1910)|original New Zealand Labour Party]] and the [[United Labour Party (New Zealand)|United Labour Party]] to the current [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] formed in 1916. He was New Zealand Labour Party president 1918 to 1920, and stood as [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] candidate for [[Dunedin South]] in [[New Zealand general election, 1919|1919]]; losing by only 84 votes against [[Thomas Sidey]] of the [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal Party]]; he did not stand for parliament again.{{sfn|Gustafson|1980|p=164}}{{sfn|Wilson|1985|p=234}} He was also involved in the WEA ([[Workers' Educational Association]]), and was Vice-President of the NZ Land Values League which expoused [[Georgism|Georgist]] policies. He was pro-conscription in World War I. In the [[1958 New Year Honours]], Paul was appointed a [[Order of the British Empire|Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] for services in the fields of journalism and government.{{London Gazette |issue= 41270 |date=1 January 1958 |page=44 |supp=y}} For many years, he looked after his ailing wife, who died in 1961. Paul died on 25 July 1964 at [[Raumati]] on the [[Kapiti Coast]]. He was survived by their two sons. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite book |ref = harv |first = Barry |last = Gustafson |authorlink = Barry Gustafson |title = Labour's path to political independence: The Origins and Establishment of the New Zealand Labour Party, 1900–19 |place = [[Auckland]], New Zealand |publisher = [[Auckland University Press]] |year = 1980 |isbn = 0-19-647986-X }} *{{cite book |ref= harv |last= Wilson |first= James Oakley |title= New Zealand Parliamentary Record, 1840–1984 |edition= 4th |origyear= First ed. published 1913 |year= 1985 |publisher= V.R. Ward, Govt. Printer |location= Wellington |oclc=154283103}} {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Andrew Walker (politician)|Andrew Walker]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[New Zealand Labour Party#List of presidents|President of the Labour Party]]|years=1918–1920}} {{s-aft|after=[[Peter Fraser]]}} {{end}} {{New Zealand Labour Party}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Paul, John Thomas}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1964 deaths]] [[Category:New Zealand journalists]] [[Category:New Zealand trade unionists]] [[Category:New Zealand Labour Party MLCs]] [[Category:Members of the New Zealand Legislative Council]] [[Category:Georgists]] [[Category:Georgist politicians]] [[Category:Australian emigrants to New Zealand]] [[Category:Unsuccessful candidates in the New Zealand general election, 1919]] [[Category:New Zealand Labour Party politicians]] [[Category:Independent Political Labour League MLCs]] [[Category:United Labour Party (New Zealand) MLCs]] [[Category:New Zealand Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]]
